sen.j: 豆板銀（まめいたぎん）は、江戸時代に流通した銀貨の一種。
sen.e: Mameitagin is a name for silver coins circulated in the Edo Period.

sen.e: They are also called Kotsubugin (pea-size silver) or Kodamagin (small ball silver).

sen.j: 当時、銀座 (歴史)において用いられた正式名称は「小玉銀」であるが、『金銀図録』および『三貨図彙』などの古銭書には「豆板銀」という名称で収録されている。
sen.e: At that time, the formal name used at Ginza (an organization in charge of casting and appraising of silver during the Edo period) was 'Kodamagin' but in the books of old coinage such as "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog) and "Sankazue" (History of Coinage in Japan), it was recorded under the name of 'Mameitagin'.
sen.cmt: 「銀座 (歴史)」の（歴史）は現在の地名としての「銀座」と区別するためにタイトルに付けられたもののようです。原文にはないので訳文では省いてあります。『金銀図録』が『』だけでしたので書名を追加しました。
sen.e: At that time, the formal name used at Ginza (an organization in charge of casting and appraising of silver during the Edo period) was 'Kodamagin,' but in the books of old coinage, such as "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog) and "Sanka zui" (Illustrations of the three types of money), it was recorded under the name of 'Mameitagin'.
sen.cmt: 『三貨図彙』：読み方を「さんかずい」とし、注釈も変更しました。http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=jFRoMVl_MDoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+bakumatsu+currency+crisis&hl=ja&ei=fKJoTIagLYXUuAOiwaH-Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=sanka&f=falseコンマを追加しました。
sen.e: At that time, the formal name used at Ginza (an organization in charge of casting and appraising of silver during the Edo period) was 'Kodamagin,' but in the books of old coinage, such as "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog) and "Sanka zui" (Illustrations of the three types of money), it was recorded under the name of 'Mameitagin'.

sen.j: 形状は小粒の銀塊で、重量は不定だが1匁（約3.75グラム）から10匁（37.5グラム）程度の秤量銀貨である。
sen.e: They are in the shape of small silver lumps and were silver-by-weight standard coins of variable weights between 1 monme (approximately 3.75g) and 10 monme (approximately 37.5g).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They were silver coins valued by weight, in the form of small silver slugs and with a weight of about 1 monme (approximately 3.75g) to 10 monme (37.5g).
Shaped like small silver slugs with a weight of between about 1 monme (approx. 3.75 g) to 10 monme (approx. 37.5 g), Mameitagin are silver coins that were valued by weight.

sen.j: 0.1匁程度の小粒のものも存在し露銀（つゆぎん）と呼ばれ、僅かな目方の調整に用いられた。
sen.e: There were also very small ones called Tsuyugin (dewdrop-beads) with a weight of 0.1 monme and used to adjust the weight.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There were also very small ones called Tsuyugin (dewdrop-beads) with a weight of 0.1 monme and used to adjust the weight.

sen.j: 表面には「常是」および「寳」に加えて年代を現す文字極印が打たれ、また片面ないし両面に大黒天像の極印が丁寧に打たれたものが存在し、恩賞および贈答用とされる。
sen.e: There are some Mameitagin with precise hallmarks of '常是' (joze[heredity name of a refiner]), '寳' (ho [valuable]) and the year they were made, with the image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) on one or both sides and they are thought to be for prizes and gifts.

Some of them had precise hallmarks of '常是' (joze[heredity name of a refiner]), '寳' (ho [valuable]) and the year they were made, and other had the image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) on one or both sides probably for prizes and gifts.

Some of these coins had precise markings ('常是' [pronounced "joze"], which was the heredity name of a refiner, and '寳' {pronounced "ho"], meaning "valuable") and the year they were made, while others were inscribed with the image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) on one or both sides, probably to indicate that they were prizes or gifts.

sen.j: それ自体を利用するほか、丁銀の補助貨幣的な役割をもつ。
sen.e: They could be used on their own or in the role of auxiliary coins of Chogin (silver coins).
They could be used on their own or in the role of auxiliary coins of Chogin (coins in the form of long oval silver slugs).
sen.cmt: 丁銀の説明を追記しました。
sen.e: They could be used on their own or in the role of auxiliary coins of Chogin (coins in the form of long oval silver slugs).

sen.j: 例えば、小さな丁銀に豆板銀を加えて重量を43匁（約161.25グラム）にあわせ、紙に包んで封印し、まとめて使用する事も行われた。
sen.e: For example, small Chogin and some Mameitagin were put together in a bag to make 43 monme (approximately 161.25g) and the bag was sealed.
For example, small Chogin and some Mameitagin weighing 43 monme (approximately 161.25g) were sealed in paper to use together.
sen.cmt: 「まとめて使用する」の訳漏れを追記するため、変更しました。
sen.e: For example, Mameitagin were sometimes added to small Chogin to give a combined weight of 43 monme (approx. 161.25 g) and then wrapped in paper for use together.

sen.j: これを包銀という。
sen.e: These are called Hogin (silver coin bags).

sen.j: 丁銀は包銀の形で大口取引に使用されることが多く日常生活で使用するには高額過ぎ、裸で使用されることはほとんどなかった。
sen.e: Chogin were used in the form of Hogin for large transactions but were too high in value to be used in everyday life, so Chogin were hardly used on their own.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Chogin were often used in the form of Hogin for large size transactions, but were hardly used on their own because they were too valuable to use in everyday life.
sen.cmt: 「～ことがが多く」の訳漏れを追記するため、変更しました。
sen.e: Chogin were often used in the form of Hogin for large size transactions, but were hardly used on their own because they were too valuable to use in everyday life.

sen.j: 豆板銀については持ち運び可能な銀秤（ぎんばかり）により随時秤量しての支払いが可能であり、また現金を銭緡（ぜにさし）で持ち歩くよりも携帯に便利で、適宜両替商で銭貨に替えて使用するなど、重宝された。
sen.e: Mameitagin were used widely because they could be weighed with a portable Ginbakari (scale for silver) to be used for immediate payment they were easier to carry around than in Zenisashi (bundled coins with a rope).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Mameitagin were used widely, as they enabled each payment by weighing them with a portable Ginbakari (scale for silver) and were exchanged into silver coins at money changers as needed because they were easier to carry than cash in Zenisashi (a string to bundle coins).
sen.cmt: 「適宜両替商で銭貨に替えて使用するなど」の訳漏れを追記するため、変更しました。
sen.e: Mameitagin were used widely, as they enabled each payment by weighing them with a portable Ginbakari (scale for silver) and were exchanged into silver coins at money changers as needed because they were easier to carry than cash in Zenisashi (a string to bundle coins).

sen.j: 元和 (日本)6年（1620年）頃に鋳造された慶長豆板銀に始まり、安政6年（1859年）の安政豆板銀まで常に丁銀と同じ銀品位で鋳造され、江戸時代を通じて発行された。
sen.e: Mameitagin production started with Keicho Mameitagin around 1620 and those coins were always made in the same quality as Chogin until Ansei Mameitagin in 1859; and were issued throughout the Edo Period.
